speaker: Provost
text_entry: SCENE IV. A room in ANGELO's house.

speaker: Provost
text_entry: Enter ANGELO

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: When I would pray and think, I think and pray

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: To several subjects. Heaven hath my empty words;

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Whilst my invention, hearing not my tongue,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Anchors on Isabel: Heaven in my mouth,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: As if I did but only chew his name;

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: And in my heart the strong and swelling evil

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Of my conception. The state, whereon I studied

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Is like a good thing, being often read,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Grown fear'd and tedious; yea, my gravity,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Wherein--let no man hear me--I take pride,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Could I with boot change for an idle plume,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Which the air beats for vain. O place, O form,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: How often dost thou with thy case, thy habit,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Wrench awe from fools and tie the wiser souls

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: To thy false seeming! Blood, thou art blood:

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Let's write good angel on the devil's horn:

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: 'Tis not the devil's crest.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Enter a Servant

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: How now! who's there?

speaker: Servant
text_entry: One Isabel, a sister, desires access to you.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Teach her the way.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Exit Servant

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: O heavens!

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Why does my blood thus muster to my heart,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Making both it unable for itself,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: And dispossessing all my other parts

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Of necessary fitness?

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: So play the foolish throngs with one that swoons;

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Come all to help him, and so stop the air

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: By which he should revive: and even so

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: The general, subject to a well-wish'd king,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Quit their own part, and in obsequious fondness

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Crowd to his presence, where their untaught love

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Must needs appear offence.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Enter ISABELLA

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: How now, fair maid?

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: I am come to know your pleasure.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: That you might know it, would much better please me

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Than to demand what 'tis. Your brother cannot live.

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Even so. Heaven keep your honour!

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Yet may he live awhile; and, it may be,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: As long as you or I yet he must die.

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Under your sentence?

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Yea.

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: When, I beseech you? that in his reprieve,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Longer or shorter, he may be so fitted

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: That his soul sicken not.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Ha! fie, these filthy vices! It were as good

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: To pardon him that hath from nature stolen

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: A man already made, as to remit

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Their saucy sweetness that do coin heaven's image

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: In stamps that are forbid: 'tis all as easy

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Falsely to take away a life true made

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: As to put metal in restrained means

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: To make a false one.

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: 'Tis set down so in heaven, but not in earth.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Say you so? then I shall pose you quickly.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Which had you rather, that the most just law

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Now took your brother's life; or, to redeem him,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Give up your body to such sweet uncleanness

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: As she that he hath stain'd?

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Sir, believe this,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: I had rather give my body than my soul.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: I talk not of your soul: our compell'd sins

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Stand more for number than for accompt.

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: How say you?

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Nay, I'll not warrant that; for I can speak

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Against the thing I say. Answer to this:

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: I, now the voice of the recorded law,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Pronounce a sentence on your brother's life:

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Might there not be a charity in sin

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: To save this brother's life?

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Please you to do't,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: I'll take it as a peril to my soul,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: It is no sin at all, but charity.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Pleased you to do't at peril of your soul,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Were equal poise of sin and charity.

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: That I do beg his life, if it be sin,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Heaven let me bear it! you granting of my suit,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: If that be sin, I'll make it my morn prayer

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: To have it added to the faults of mine,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: And nothing of your answer.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Nay, but hear me.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Your sense pursues not mine: either you are ignorant,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Or seem so craftily; and that's not good.

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Let me be ignorant, and in nothing good,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: But graciously to know I am no better.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Thus wisdom wishes to appear most bright

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: When it doth tax itself; as these black masks

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Proclaim an enshield beauty ten times louder

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Than beauty could, display'd. But mark me;

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: To be received plain, I'll speak more gross:

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Your brother is to die.

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: So.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: And his offence is so, as it appears,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Accountant to the law upon that pain.

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: True.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Admit no other way to save his life,--

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: As I subscribe not that, nor any other,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: But in the loss of question,--that you, his sister,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Finding yourself desired of such a person,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Whose credit with the judge, or own great place,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Could fetch your brother from the manacles

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Of the all-building law; and that there were

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: No earthly mean to save him, but that either

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: You must lay down the treasures of your body

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: To this supposed, or else to let him suffer;

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: What would you do?

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: As much for my poor brother as myself:

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: That is, were I under the terms of death,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: The impression of keen whips I'ld wear as rubies,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: And strip myself to death, as to a bed

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: That longing have been sick for, ere I'ld yield

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: My body up to shame.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Then must your brother die.

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: And 'twere the cheaper way:

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Better it were a brother died at once,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Than that a sister, by redeeming him,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Should die for ever.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Were not you then as cruel as the sentence

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: That you have slander'd so?

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Ignomy in ransom and free pardon

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Are of two houses: lawful mercy

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Is nothing kin to foul redemption.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: You seem'd of late to make the law a tyrant;

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: And rather proved the sliding of your brother

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: A merriment than a vice.

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: O, pardon me, my lord; it oft falls out,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: To have what we would have, we speak not what we mean:

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: I something do excuse the thing I hate,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: For his advantage that I dearly love.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: We are all frail.

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Else let my brother die,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: If not a feodary, but only he

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Owe and succeed thy weakness.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Nay, women are frail too.

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Ay, as the glasses where they view themselves;

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Which are as easy broke as they make forms.

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Women! Help Heaven! men their creation mar

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: In profiting by them. Nay, call us ten times frail;

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: For we are soft as our complexions are,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: And credulous to false prints.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: I think it well:

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: And from this testimony of your own sex,--

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Since I suppose we are made to be no stronger

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Than faults may shake our frames,--let me be bold;

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: I do arrest your words. Be that you are,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: That is, a woman; if you be more, you're none;

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: If you be one, as you are well express'd

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: By all external warrants, show it now,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: By putting on the destined livery.

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: I have no tongue but one: gentle my lord,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Let me entreat you speak the former language.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Plainly conceive, I love you.

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: My brother did love Juliet,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: And you tell me that he shall die for it.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: He shall not, Isabel, if you give me love.

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: I know your virtue hath a licence in't,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Which seems a little fouler than it is,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: To pluck on others.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Believe me, on mine honour,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: My words express my purpose.

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Ha! little honour to be much believed,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: And most pernicious purpose! Seeming, seeming!

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: I will proclaim thee, Angelo; look for't:

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Sign me a present pardon for my brother,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Or with an outstretch'd throat I'll tell the world aloud

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: What man thou art.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Who will believe thee, Isabel?

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: My unsoil'd name, the austereness of my life,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: My vouch against you, and my place i' the state,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Will so your accusation overweigh,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: That you shall stifle in your own report

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: And smell of calumny. I have begun,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: And now I give my sensual race the rein:

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Fit thy consent to my sharp appetite;

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Lay by all nicety and prolixious blushes,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: That banish what they sue for; redeem thy brother

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: By yielding up thy body to my will;

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Or else he must not only die the death,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: But thy unkindness shall his death draw out

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: To lingering sufferance. Answer me to-morrow,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Or, by the affection that now guides me most,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: I'll prove a tyrant to him. As for you,

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Say what you can, my false o'erweighs your true.

speaker: ANGELO
text_entry: Exit

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: To whom should I complain? Did I tell this,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Who would believe me? O perilous mouths,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: That bear in them one and the self-same tongue,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Either of condemnation or approof;

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Bidding the law make court'sy to their will:

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Hooking both right and wrong to the appetite,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: To follow as it draws! I'll to my brother:

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Though he hath fallen by prompture of the blood,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Yet hath he in him such a mind of honour.

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: That, had he twenty heads to tender down

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: On twenty bloody blocks, he'ld yield them up,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Before his sister should her body stoop

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: To such abhorr'd pollution.

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Then, Isabel, live chaste, and, brother, die:

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: More than our brother is our chastity.

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: I'll tell him yet of Angelo's request,

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: And fit his mind to death, for his soul's rest.

speaker: ISABELLA
text_entry: Exit
